instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5.18V - 0.035A
threads.message:
Hello, first time troubleshooting this, not a trained shop person but a somewhat skilled muggle.

I have a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no liquid damage with 5.18V - 0.035A draw from original charger:

-  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0V
- <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> pin 3: 4.94V

Suspect short on <CAPACITOR>C6907</CAPACITOR>: got 4.6v goin in, 0V going out. Full continuity to ground on <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> pin 2. Full continuity to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. Any way of testing the cap?

Any ideas?

Thank you for your time!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5.18V - 0.035A
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"Full continuity to ground on <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> pin 2. Full continuity to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>."
So you have short to ground on both <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Post exact resistance value (ohm scale).

Remove <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> and check on which pad remains the short to ground.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5.18V - 0.035A
threads.message: I have exact same readings. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0,0V and <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is also 0,0V. <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> is getting 5volts but no output on <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. Can we say that 100% the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> is bad, or is there also an enable signal for the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP>? No short found on <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5.18V - 0.035A
threads.message: Please open new thread with your problem...
